claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination induces type I interferon signaling and is associated with expanded antigen presentation on MHC-I.

evidence.quote: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
| Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape |
A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: The report summarizes mechanistic steps, but notes that some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: The combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in a retrospective human cohort stratified by SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

evidence.quote: Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.
| Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment |
- Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely, so alignment with better outcomes does not establish causality.

claims.claim: The reported sensitization effect is conditional on the mRNA-triggered type I interferon pathway, based on particle controls and IFNAR1 blockade results.

evidence.quote: Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: These perturbation controls are described in the report, but the overall findings are from preclinical systems and may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.

claims.claim: Prospective randomized studies are required before changing clinical protocols based on the reported tumor-sensitization effects.

evidence.quote: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

The study supports a biologically coherent hypothesis that intratumoral mRNA vaccination can prime tumors for stronger ICI responses, but prospective randomized studies are required before clinical protocol changes are justified.

claims.caveat: This is a cautious interpretive conclusion; it does not quantify how large a benefit would be expected in a future randomized trial.
